nodes.bodyText:
One thing I don't like about this is that it causes the interface to have an explicit dependency on one of the implementations. This would make it difficult if we decided to split these up into separate modules as this module would always have to depend on the implementation.
We could consider if this is worth changing, if it is I don't think there is a convenient solution that avoids changing a bunch of code. One solution would be to remove the copy method from the interface, then add a factory method to the existing mutable bean that takes an interface type and produces a bean copy of that object. That way the decision of typing the mutable object is pushed down to the client, they would explicitly decide they want to get a copy using the JAXB object via its new factory method.
This would apply to all the new interfaces with toMutableCopy() methods.
I didn't really think of this possibility when we were originally discussing how to produce these copies.

+    Boolean hasUpdateFields();
+    IManagedObject getManagedObject();
+    AlarmData toMutableCopy();

nodes.bodyText:
Mapping from mutable to immutable types is now handled in utility class 'Mapper'.
The mapping from immutable to mutable in the 'Mapper' utility class as well... but I'll move these factory methods to the beans themselves (as per your comment).
The listeners shouldn't need to have knowledge of the 'Mapper'.
I'll update the PR momentarily...

nodes.bodyText:
Looking at this, I think there is value in updating the original bean implementations to implement the new interface. That way these fromMutable() methods can be replaced with usage of newBuilderFrom().build().
This applies to all the new immutables.
Also this removes the dependency of the jaxb type from the immutable types in case we want to separate them.
Gave this a try - but unfortunately didn't work out.  Will go with your earlier suggestion.

The immutables should no longer need to import the JAXB objects.
Double check the other immutables as well.

nodes.bodyText:
Minor nitpick. The null check here isn't necessary since the copyFrom() methods already handle the null case.
Can update this in the other usages as well.
Done, removed the unnecessary null checks.

We don't need to use copyListFromNullable() here since we already have a new list in this object.
That method is meant to be used for fields that aren't already initialized so it creates a new list.
Double check if this is being done in the other JAXB objects.
